section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards, Magnetic Letters, paper

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Please Play Safe! and we saw the letters Nn, Rr, and Xx.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Nn Alphabet Cards This is uppercase N and this is lowercase n. The letter Nn makes the /n/ sound you hear in the words nest and nut.
Review Rr Alphabet Cards This is uppercase R and this is lowercase r. The letter Rr makes the /r/ sound you hear in the words ring and rabbit.
Review Xx Alphabet Cards This is uppercase X and this is lowercase x. The letter Xx makes the /ks/ sound that begins x-ray and ends box.

Explain the Activity Today we are going to do a matching activity where we say a word, listen to the sound, and match the letter, using pictures as clues. We will practice with the letters Nn, Rr, and Xx.
Set Up Distribute Magnetic Letters (Nn, Rr, and Xx) to each child in the group and display the Alphabet Cards. Point to and say the word on the card aloud. Have children repeat.
Ask After children repeat the word, ask them to say which sound they hear at the beginning of the word. Invite children to select the corresponding Magnetic Letter and place it on the card.
Repeat Continue the activity with all of the cards.
Practice Writing Letters Have children practice writing the letters Nn, Rr, and Xx. Have them draw a picture next to each letter that begins with Nn or Rr and ends with Xx.
Help children identify the sound by saying the words slowly. Guide children to match the letter and sound correctly, using the Alphabet Cards as support. Gradually fade your support.
Have children identify other sounds they hear in the words and ask if they can identify the letter.
In Spanish, the letter Xx is usually pronounced as /s/. Children will be more comfortable with the letter-sound correspondence /ks/ in the word fox rather than the hard /x/ in the word x-ray.

To help children with auditory discrimination challenges, invite children to cover their ears and listen as they make the letter sounds. Provide children with small mirrors and invite them to look at the position of their mouths, tongues, and teeth.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Ball

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Please Play Safe! We saw how important it is to be safe when playing outside with friends. We saw how important it is to take turns when we play with others.
We talked about being careful when we are around other people. One of the ways we can be careful when we play is to take turns.

In this activity, we will use a ball to help us practice taking turns. I will ask a question. If you want to answer it, raise your hand, and I will roll the ball to you. If you have the ball, then it’s your turn to talk.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Have children sit in a circle. Begin with a practice question: What is your favorite toy? Remind children to raise their hands if they want to answer. Roll the ball to the first child. When he or she is finished, the child will roll the ball back to you. Roll the ball to another child who has raised their hand.
Ask Ask children open-ended questions they will want to answer: What’s your favorite color? What is your favorite food? What song do you like to sing? What color is in a rainbow?
Repeat Continue the activity with questions, encouraging children to take turns and also to listen to the responses of their friends.

Talk About Waiting Point out that sometimes it’s hard to wait for your turn. Share ideas about how to make waiting easier. Suggestions may include counting in your head, singing a song, or tapping your fingers.

If children do not raise their hands to answer the questions, it may be because they cannot think of an answer. Be sure to invite those children to participate and help them by asking a really simple question and helping them formulate the answer.
Encourage children to roll the ball to another child who has his or her hand raised instead of you. Invite children to become the one who asks the questions.

To give support for multilingual learners, you may want to provide a sentence frame to help children formulate their answers. Or you may find it best to provide choices for children. For example, “Do you like red or blue?”

Some children may have difficulty waiting for their turn. Reward children who have short attention spans by recognizing that they have their hand raised, and they are doing well waiting for their turn to get the ball.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Paper, red and green crayons, Activity Cards, Vocabulary Cards

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story Please Play Safe! and we learned how Penguin helped his friend play safely at the playground. When he saw his friends doing something wrong, he helped them learn the right way to do it. We should always do things to help us keep safe.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Use the Vocabulary Card to reteach the word wrong.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: For this activity, I will show you a picture, and we will talk about whether or not the child is doing something to stay safe. You will hold up a green light if the child is being safe and red light if the child is not.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Materials Give each child two pieces of construction paper. Have them draw a red circle on one and a green circle on the other.
Ask Show one Activity Card and ask the question on the back. Have children hold up a red circle for the wrong or unsafe behavior and a green circle for right or safe behavior.
Repeat Continue the activity using the next Activity Cards.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Let’s all remember to stay safe. You can be like Penguin and remind your friends about how to play safely. What are some things you might tell them?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: As you show each picture, children may need more explanation in order to be able to focus on what is happening in the picture. Take time to show and discuss each picture. You may only be able to complete one or two.

Ask children to share other ideas they have about things that help to keep them safe. Have them draw pictures to share that show children sitting in car seats and children wearing helmets when riding bikes, scooters, or skating.

Help multilingual learners to understand how the words yes/no and right/wrong have similar meanings. Explain that red lights mean “stop” and green lights mean “go.” The red circle signifies that the behavior is wrong. The green circle signifies that the behavior is right.

Most children will benefit from physical practice time at the playground. Demonstrate how far one should be from the swings when in use. Show the proper way to sit on the swing and the slide and how to use both hands. Have children model these best playground practices.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Craft Sticks, paper plates, glue, sticky notes, crayons

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the Big Chart of Big Ideas: Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed. We counted froggies and talked about why they should not be jumping on the bed.
In this activity, we will create our own froggies and act out the rhyme. We will practice counting forward and backwards, one through five!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Have children color half a paper plate as their frog. Encourage them to add eyes and a mouth. Glue their plates onto the craft sticks. Use your sticky notes to number the froggies 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5.
Ask Ask children questions about the rhyme: How many froggies were jumping on the bed? What happens when one bumps its head?

Perform Sing or play a recording of the song, as children sing along. Have children stand in numerical order and act out the rhyme using their puppets. Invite them to count aloud—one through five, forward and backward.

Talk About Following Rules Have children share with a partner what happens when the froggies did not listen to their doctor or to their mother. Invite children to answer the question: What can happen when friends do not follow the rules?
Assist children to create their puppets. Count the number of froggie puppets aloud and invite children to repeat after you.
Place the numbered puppets randomly on a table. Encourage children to rearrange them in numerical order, one through five. Then, have them arrange the puppets in descending order.

Write out the words and numbers for each froggie and practice saying the words aloud, using your fingers to demonstrate how many. Once children have practiced several times, say the number and have children select the puppet with the corresponding number.

Encourage fine motor development by inviting children to use their stick puppets to demonstrate how the froggies jump on the bed. Using their fingers to hold the sticks and using their arms to imitate jumping helps children become aware of their own body in their own personal space.
